natural problem: Three cards are dealt at random from a standard deck (13 clubs, 13 diamonds, 13 hearts, and 13 spades) of 52 cards.  What is the probability that all three cards are $\heartsuit$s?

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes num_hearts num_cards total_cards :: nat
assumes h0 : "num_hearts = 13"
and h1 : "num_cards = 3"
and h2 : "total_cards = 52"
shows  "probability (all_cards_hearts num_cards) = 11 / 850"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Three cards are dealt at random from a standard deck (13 clubs, 13 diamonds, 13 hearts, and 13 spades) of 52 cards.  What is the probability that all three cards are $\heartsuit$s? The final Answer is \frac{11}{850}
 ### Proof
 The probability is $\dfrac{13}{52} \times \dfrac{12}{51} \times \dfrac{11}{50} = \boxed{\frac{11}{850}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes num_hearts num_cards total_cards :: nat
assumes h0 : "num_hearts = 13"
and h1 : "num_cards = 3"
and h2 : "total_cards = 52"
shows  "probability (all_cards_hearts num_cards) = 11 / 850"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: What is the probability of drawing 3 cards, all of which are hearts, from a standard deck of 52 playing cards (which has 13 hearts)? The final answer is $\frac{11}{850}$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes probability :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. probability n = (card {x. x \<in> {1..52} \<and> x \<in> \<heartsuit>}) / (card {x. x \<in> {1..52}})"
and h1 : "card {x. x \<in> {1..52} \<and> x \<in> \<heartsuit>} = 13"
and h2 : "card {x. x \<in> {1..52}} = 52"
shows  "probability 3 = 11 / 850"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Three cards are dealt at random from a standard deck (13 clubs, 13 diamonds, 13 hearts, and 13 spades) of 52 cards.  What is the probability that all three cards are $\heartsuit$s? The final Answer is \frac{11}{850}
 ### Proof
 The probability is $\dfrac{13}{52} \times \dfrac{12}{51} \times \dfrac{11}{50} = \boxed{\frac{11}{850}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes probability :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. probability n = (card {x. x \<in> {1..52} \<and> x \<in> \<heartsuit>}) / (card {x. x \<in> {1..52}})"
and h1 : "card {x. x \<in> {1..52} \<and> x \<in> \<heartsuit>} = 13"
and h2 : "card {x. x \<in> {1..52}} = 52"
shows  "probability 3 = 11 / 850"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: In a deck of 52 playing cards, what is the probability of drawing 3 cards from the same suit (hearts)? The final answer is $\frac{11}{850}$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes probability :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "probability = (\<lambda>p. p * (p - 1) * (p - 2) / (52 * 51 * 50))"
shows  "probability 13 = 11 / 850"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Three cards are dealt at random from a standard deck (13 clubs, 13 diamonds, 13 hearts, and 13 spades) of 52 cards.  What is the probability that all three cards are $\heartsuit$s? The final Answer is \frac{11}{850}
 ### Proof
 The probability is $\dfrac{13}{52} \times \dfrac{12}{51} \times \dfrac{11}{50} = \boxed{\frac{11}{850}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes probability :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "probability = (\<lambda>p. p * (p - 1) * (p - 2) / (52 * 51 * 50))"
shows  "probability 13 = 11 / 850"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Given a probability function defined as $p(p-1)(p-2)/(52 * 51 * 50)$, find the probability when $p = 13$. The final answer is $\frac{11}{850}$.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes prob :: real
assumes h0 : "prob = (13/52) * (12/51) * (11/50)"
shows  "prob = 11 / 850"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Three cards are dealt at random from a standard deck (13 clubs, 13 diamonds, 13 hearts, and 13 spades) of 52 cards.  What is the probability that all three cards are $\heartsuit$s? The final Answer is \frac{11}{850}
 ### Proof
 The probability is $\dfrac{13}{52} \times \dfrac{12}{51} \times \dfrac{11}{50} = \boxed{\frac{11}{850}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes prob :: real
assumes h0 : "prob = (13/52) * (12/51) * (11/50)"
shows  "prob = 11 / 850"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Find the probability of drawing three consecutive cards from a standard 52-card deck with 13 cards of each suit, such that all three cards are of the same suit. The final answer is $\frac{11}{850}$.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes total_cards num_hearts drawn_cards :: real
assumes h0 : "total_cards = 52"
and h1 : "num_hearts = 13"
and h2 : "drawn_cards = 3"
shows  "prob_draw_all_hearts = (11 / 850)"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Three cards are dealt at random from a standard deck (13 clubs, 13 diamonds, 13 hearts, and 13 spades) of 52 cards.  What is the probability that all three cards are $\heartsuit$s? The final Answer is \frac{11}{850}
 ### Proof
 The probability is $\dfrac{13}{52} \times \dfrac{12}{51} \times \dfrac{11}{50} = \boxed{\frac{11}{850}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes total_cards num_hearts drawn_cards :: real
assumes h0 : "total_cards = 52"
and h1 : "num_hearts = 13"
and h2 : "drawn_cards = 3"
shows  "prob_draw_all_hearts = (11 / 850)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: If there are 52 cards in a deck with 13 hearts, what is the probability of drawing 3 cards and having all of them be hearts? The final answer is $\frac{11}{850}$.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes probability :: real
assumes h0 : "probability = (card {x. x \<in> {1..13} \<and> suit x = hearts}) / (card {x. x \<in> {1..52}})"
and h1 : "card {x. x \<in> {1..13} \<and> suit x = hearts} = 3"
and h2 : "card {x. x \<in> {1..52}} = 49"
shows  "probability = 11 / 850"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Three cards are dealt at random from a standard deck (13 clubs, 13 diamonds, 13 hearts, and 13 spades) of 52 cards.  What is the probability that all three cards are $\heartsuit$s? The final Answer is \frac{11}{850}
 ### Proof
 The probability is $\dfrac{13}{52} \times \dfrac{12}{51} \times \dfrac{11}{50} = \boxed{\frac{11}{850}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes probability :: real
assumes h0 : "probability = (card {x. x \<in> {1..13} \<and> suit x = hearts}) / (card {x. x \<in> {1..52}})"
and h1 : "card {x. x \<in> {1..13} \<and> suit x = hearts} = 3"
and h2 : "card {x. x \<in> {1..52}} = 49"
shows  "probability = 11 / 850"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: In a deck of 52 cards, there are 49 cards left with 3 of them being hearts. What is the probability of drawing a heart from the remaining cards? The final answer is $\frac{11}{850}$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes probability :: real
assumes h0 : "probability = (13 choose 3) / (52 choose 3)"
shows  "probability = 11 / 850"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Three cards are dealt at random from a standard deck (13 clubs, 13 diamonds, 13 hearts, and 13 spades) of 52 cards.  What is the probability that all three cards are $\heartsuit$s? The final Answer is \frac{11}{850}
 ### Proof
 The probability is $\dfrac{13}{52} \times \dfrac{12}{51} \times \dfrac{11}{50} = \boxed{\frac{11}{850}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes probability :: real
assumes h0 : "probability = (13 choose 3) / (52 choose 3)"
shows  "probability = 11 / 850"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: What is the probability of choosing exactly 3 cards out of 13 from a standard 52-card deck? Express your answer as a fraction. The final answer is $\frac{11}{850}$.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes probability :: "real"
assumes h0 : "probability = (\<lambda>(success, total). success / total) (card {hearts1, hearts2, hearts3})"
and h1 : "hearts1 \<in> {1..13}"
and h2 : "hearts2 \<in> {1..13} - {hearts1}"
and h3 : "hearts3 \<in> {1..13} - {hearts1, hearts2}"
and h4 : "card {hearts1, hearts2, hearts3} = 3"
and h5 : "card {1..52} = 52"
shows  "probability = 11 / 850"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Three cards are dealt at random from a standard deck (13 clubs, 13 diamonds, 13 hearts, and 13 spades) of 52 cards.  What is the probability that all three cards are $\heartsuit$s? The final Answer is \frac{11}{850}
 ### Proof
 The probability is $\dfrac{13}{52} \times \dfrac{12}{51} \times \dfrac{11}{50} = \boxed{\frac{11}{850}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes probability :: "real"
assumes h0 : "probability = (\<lambda>(success, total). success / total) (card {hearts1, hearts2, hearts3})"
and h1 : "hearts1 \<in> {1..13}"
and h2 : "hearts2 \<in> {1..13} - {hearts1}"
and h3 : "hearts3 \<in> {1..13} - {hearts1, hearts2}"
and h4 : "card {hearts1, hearts2, hearts3} = 3"
and h5 : "card {1..52} = 52"
shows  "probability = 11 / 850"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: What is the probability of drawing three distinct cards of hearts from a standard 52-card deck without replacement? The final answer is $\frac{11}{850}$.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes probability :: "real"
assumes h0 : "probability = (13 * 12 * 11) / (52 * 51 * 50)"
shows  "probability = 11 / 850"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Three cards are dealt at random from a standard deck (13 clubs, 13 diamonds, 13 hearts, and 13 spades) of 52 cards.  What is the probability that all three cards are $\heartsuit$s? The final Answer is \frac{11}{850}
 ### Proof
 The probability is $\dfrac{13}{52} \times \dfrac{12}{51} \times \dfrac{11}{50} = \boxed{\frac{11}{850}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes probability :: "real"
assumes h0 : "probability = (13 * 12 * 11) / (52 * 51 * 50)"
shows  "probability = 11 / 850"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Calculate the probability of drawing three face cards (King, Queen, or Jack) in a row from a standard deck of 52 playing cards without replacement. The final answer is $\frac{11}{850}$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes probability :: real
assumes h0 : "probability = (card {x. x in {1..13} \<and> \<heartsuit>}) / (card {x. x in {1..52}})"
and h1 : "probability * (card {x. x in {1..12} \<and> \<heartsuit>}) / (card {x. x in {1..51}})"
and h2 : "probability * (card {x. x in {1..11} \<and> \<heartsuit>}) / (card {x. x in {1..50}})"
shows  "probability = 11 / 850"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Three cards are dealt at random from a standard deck (13 clubs, 13 diamonds, 13 hearts, and 13 spades) of 52 cards.  What is the probability that all three cards are $\heartsuit$s? The final Answer is \frac{11}{850}
 ### Proof
 The probability is $\dfrac{13}{52} \times \dfrac{12}{51} \times \dfrac{11}{50} = \boxed{\frac{11}{850}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes probability :: real
assumes h0 : "probability = (card {x. x in {1..13} \<and> \<heartsuit>}) / (card {x. x in {1..52}})"
and h1 : "probability * (card {x. x in {1..12} \<and> \<heartsuit>}) / (card {x. x in {1..51}})"
and h2 : "probability * (card {x. x in {1..11} \<and> \<heartsuit>}) / (card {x. x in {1..50}})"
shows  "probability = 11 / 850"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: What is the probability of drawing three cards with hearts consecutively from a standard deck of 52 cards without replacement? The final answer is $\frac{11}{850}$.
